options: Give her details of a domestic violence support group
Refer her son to the Children and Adolescent Mental Health Service
Contact the local Child Protection Officer
Phone her partner after surgery and make it clear such behaviour must stop
Advise her to attend self-defence classes
Make a note to offer an anger management course to the partner the next time you see him
Make a follow-up appointment for next week
Explore why she is making her partner so angry
questions:
A 23-year-old woman comes in with depression. Immediately you notice bruising on the left side of her face. She tells you her partner got angry as her 3-year-old boy threw his food on the floor during a family meal. When she told him not to shout at her son her partner slapped her across the face. The patient describes her son as having 'too much energy'. Her partner has never harmed, or threaten to harm, her son and she does not want police involvement.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Domestic violence witnessed by a child is now classified as a form of abuse. It is therefore appropriate to contact the local Child Protection Officer. A domestic violence support group may be able to offer her practical advice and arrange a possible refuge. Making a follow-up appointment is good practice as it allows you to assess progress.

Referring her son to the Children and Adolescent Mental Health Service implies this is the root cause of the problems, rather that her partners violence. It is normal for 3-year-olds to be full of energy and referral is not necessary at this point. Whilst it may be argued that self-defence classes offer practical help it does not address the root cause and may lead to an escalation of violence.

Discussing this with her partner both breaks confidentiality and also puts the patient at risk from retribution.

options: Call the on-call pharmacist for advice
Ask the consultant their reason for prescribing that particular antibiotic
Prescribe the antibiotic that the consultant recommended
Ignore the consultant's prescription and write up a separate prescription according to hospital guidelines
Show the consultant the hospital guidelines and ask if they still want to prescribe the antibiotic
questions: You are a ST1 doctor working on a care of the elderly ward. A locum consultant prescribes an antibiotic for one of the patients on the ward, for her urinary tract infection. You know this particular antibiotic is outside hospital guidelines. What should you do?
notes:
The most appropriate response is to ask the consultant their reason for not prescribing the guideline antibiotic. They may have a reason as to the specific antibiotic prescribed.

Showing the consultant the hospital guidelines is the next most appropriate response as it deals with the issue and the consultant may not have been aware of the different prescribing guidelines in that particular area.

Calling the on-call pharmacist is a good option as you are seeking professional advice rather than making your own decision without support.

Prescribing the consultant's recommended antibiotic is less appropriate as you would be ignoring guidelines that you know to be in place. However, making the decision on your own would be the least appropriate option as you would not only be undermining the consultant's decision but if something happened to the patient and you ignored the consultant's advice you would be responsible.

options: Call the consultant in charge and explain the situation
Continue working on the ward as you are already short-staffed
Ask a registrar from a neighbouring ward to come and help with the workload
Raise your concerns with the registrar and suggest that they go home
Report the registrar to the GMC
questions:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working on the geriatrics ward. Your registrar arrives late and smells strongly of alcohol. The other junior doctors are off on sick leave and it is only you and your registrar on the ward today.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
This question focuses on patient safety and the professionalism of your colleagues. In this scenario, we are met with a registrar who has turned up to work late and smells strongly of alcohol. There is a high suspicion that this registrar may either be hungover or still under the influence of alcohol. Nevertheless, there is a considerable risk to patient safety with impaired decision-making capabilities.

The most appropriate option would be to raise your concerns with the registrar and suggest that they go home (D) - this gives your registrar an opportunity to recognise that they are unable to work effectively and are risking patient safety. Following this, the consultant in charge should be informed of the situation (A) - even if your colleague recognises that they need to go home due to intoxication, there is a significant burden of work being placed on you as the only doctor on the ward, and this needs immediate escalation. Asking a registrar from a neighbouring ward to come and help with the workload (C) is less appropriate. Although it may address your own workload, it does not address the underlying issue of your colleague coming in whilst intoxicated and puts a significant burden on the registrar, who now may have to cover 2 wards. Reporting your registrar to the GMC (E) is unwarranted at this stage. However, there should be an internal investigation with the registrar and their educational supervisor with a reflection on their behaviour. The least appropriate option is to continue working on the ward as you are already short-staffed - this ignores the fact that your senior has come in intoxicated which has huge patient safety implications.

title: GMC: Raising and acting on concerns about patient safety
body:
The GMC take a firm line on patient safety, in that you must take action if you think patient safety, dignity or comfort is being compromised. This is not always easy, particularly as a student or junior doctor- which is why it is important to be aware of the guidance.

Broad Principles

All doctors have the duty to raise concerns if they believe that patient safety or care is being compromised. This can include when medical students witness poor practice on placement, or family members raise concerns. They must also encourage and support a culture in which staff can raise concerns openly and safely.

Concerns may relate to:
  • The practice of colleagues,
  • The systems in place,
  • Policies and procedures within organisations.

You may be reluctant to report a concern for a number of reasons, particularly if you have not needed to raise concerns in the past. For example:
  • You fear that nothing will be done,
  • You fear that raising your concern may cause problems for colleagues,
  • It could have a negative effect on working relationships or career,
  • It could result in a complaint about you.

While it is natural to have these concerns, keep the following in mind:
  • You have a duty to put patients' interests first and act to protect them. This should override personal and professional loyalties.
  • The law provides legal protection. This is against victimisation or dismissal for individuals who reveal information to raise genuine concerns and expose malpractice in the workplace.
  • You do not need to wait for proof. You can justify raising a concern if you do so honestly, on the basis of reasonable belief and through appropriate channels.

For example, you may believe that a member of staff is intentionally avoiding guidance on hand-washing. When reporting this, you must be clear, honest and objective about the reason for your concern. You should also keep a record of any steps that you have taken to deal with it.

Who to report to

Wherever possible, you should first raise your concern with your manager or an appropriate officer, such as:
  • The consultant in charge of the team,
  • The clinical or medical director,
  • A practice partner.

NB: If your concern is about a partner, it may be appropriate to raise it outside the practice.

If you are a doctor in training, it may be appropriate to raise your concerns with a named person in the deanery. One example could be where a senior clinician has been reported by a number of patients for improper practice, and you would like to seek further advise on what action to take.

You should contact a regulatory body, such as the General Medical Council, in the following circumstances.
  • If you cannot raise the issue with the responsible person or body locally because you believe them to be part of the problem.
  • If you have raised your concern through local channels but are not satisfied that the responsible person or body has taken adequate action.
  • If there is an immediate serious risk to patients, and a regulator or other external body has responsibility to act or intervene.

It is not common to raise concerns publicly, as they can usually be dealt with discretely by the appropriate team. However, you can consider making your concerns public if you:
  • Have done all you can to deal with any concern by raising it within the organisation in which you work or which you have contract with, or with the appropriate external body, and
  • Have good reason to believe that patients are still at risk of harm,
  • Do not breach patient confidentiality.

Acting on Concerns

As a medical student or recently qualified doctor, you may not need to do more than report concerns. However, concerns about patient safety can also come from a number of sources, such as:
  • Patients' complaints,
  • Colleagues' concerns,
  • Critical incident reports,
  • Clinical audit.

If you receive this information, you have a responsibility to act on it promptly and professionally. You can do this by putting the matter right (if possible), investigating and dealing with it locally, or referring serious or repeated incidents to senior management.

If you have a management role or responsibility, you must make sure that:
  • There are systems and policies in place to allow concerns and investigated promptly and fully,
  • You do not try to prevent employees or former employees raising concerns about patient safety,
  • Clinical staff understand their duty to be open and honest about incidents or complaints with both patients and managers,
  • Staff who raise a concern are protected from unfair criticism or action, including any detriment or dismissal.

If you are responsible for investigating incidents or complaints, you must:
  • Tell the person what action has been taken to prevent a recurrence of the problem,
  • Outline the process if they are still not satisfied with the response,
  • Ensure that any investigations or resulting actions are carried out in a way which is consistent with the law.

options: Transfer the patient to another hospital
Ask the anaesthetists to review as he may require surgery
Ask the medical registrar to review
Phone the on-call surgical consultant
Leave a message with the scrub-nurse asking her to review the patient after she has finished
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in surgery. During a night shift the nurses ask you to review a patient who has 'gone off'. Two days previously he had surgery for colorectal cancer. On arriving the patient is conscious but complaining of abdominal pain. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg and pulse is 114 bpm. You notice that his abdomen is distended. You initiate basic management using an ABC approach and send bloods. On bleeping the registrar and explaining the situation you are informed by a scrub nurse that she is in theatre with a trauma patient.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question looks at a scenario where you have a poorly patient but are struggling to get senior support.

If the surgical registrar is stuck in theatre then the consultant on-call needs to be informed immediately as he/she may need to come in. The next best person to contact is the anaesthetist as it is possible that the patient may need to go back to theatre. The medical registrar may be able to offer assistance in view of their experience and procedural skills but this is really the last resort.

Leaving a message is inappropriate given how poorly the patient is. The patient is too poorly to be transferred.

options: Speak to the patient and tell him that this is unacceptable behaviour
Prescribe Lorazepam to calm the patient down
Tell the nurse that there is nothing you can do and there are already plenty of nurses there
Tell the nurse that there isn't anything you can do and to ring security
Calmly speak to the patient and explore his reasons for being angry
questions:
Whilst working on the respiratory ward, you overhear an elderly patient shouting, swearing and verbally abusing one of the nurses. One of the other nurses asks for your assistance in the matter.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
In the setting of an agitated and angry patient, de-escalation techniques are key in an attempt to try and calm the patient down. There may be a key reason for his anger and by taking the time to speak to him you may find you can get to the bottom of why he is acting out this way.

Speaking to the patient yourself to try and figure out whether there is something underlying his anger e.g. he may be confused, should be the first thing you do.

However, if this is not an option then as a doctor you should show your ability to support your fellow team. The patient clearly isn't listening to anything the nurse has to say and may be more receptive to a doctor. Therefore telling him that his behaviour is unacceptable (option A) to see if he responds to you would be the next best choice.

If the patient refuses to listen to either you or nurse then that should trigger you to escalate the situation and get security involved (option D).

C shows poor team work and an inability to support your colleague when needed hence why it is ranked lower down.

B is the worst option. Prescribing a sedative without the patients consent purely because he is angry is not acceptable and may be seen as assaulting the patient.

options: Ring the microbiologist on call to ask for advice

questions:
You are asked to prescribe a patient with sepsis tazocin (piperacillin and tazobactam). When you check his chart, you see that he is allergic to penicillin based antibiotics.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Checking the formulary for your Trust alternative antibiotic is your first action in this situation. If an alternative antibiotic is not suggested then the microbiologist on call will provide advice once the patient has been discussed in detail with regards to the reason for antibiotic treatment.

Handing over jobs to your registrar is something that needs to be reserved for more complex situations than this one. Not prescribing any antibiotics is very dangerous if the patient has an infection, but the most dangerous of all is prescribing an antibiotic that the patient has a documented allergy to.

As the GMC states '16. prescribe drugs or treatment, including repeat prescriptions, only when you have adequate knowledge of the patient's health and are satisfied that the drugs or treatment serve the patient's needs.

options: Go and visit the child immediately
Refuse to visit
Refuse to visit + remove the mother from the practice list
Offer to see the child in surgery straightaway, if mother refuses go and visit child
Phone for an ambulance
questions:
You are a GP registrar. There is a home visit request for a 4-year-old boy. The family are well known for making inappropriate home visit requests. On phoning the mother she tells you he is 'sick' and refuses to bring him to surgery because 'that's why I pay my taxes'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is an extremely annoying scenario for many GP's. The key however is to act in a professional way that is in the best interests of the child. It is important to remember that there is a small chance that the child may indeed be very ill and from a medico-legal perspective it is important not to refuse to visit a child.

Offering to see the child in surgery straightaway may persuade the mother to come in if she is genuinely concerned about her son's welfare. If she refuses then it is necessary to visit the child to ensure they are not acutely unwell. Phoning for an ambulance ensures the child receives medical attention but is an inappropriate use of resources.

Refusing to visit is wrong for the reasons already mentioned. Removal from the practice list is not justified unless there are continued problems.

options: Speak with your consultant about this issue
Take some annual leave to give yourself time to rest
Continue on with your usual jobs and keep it to yourself
Ask a colleague to help with your tasks
Consult your GP regarding your back pain
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the emergency department of a busy hospital. The job is very demanding, but you are well organised and you cope well. However, you have the ongoing issue of back pain, which has started to disturb your sleep. You find yourself increasingly tired during shifts, with a reduced ability to concentrate on and remember tasks.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most appropriate course of action for this scenario would be to consult with your GP regarding your back pain (5). This is the only option for the scenario that deals with the root of the problem and seeks a solution. The next most important option would be to speak with your consultant and explain the problems you have been experiencing (1). This is so that you can get their advice on how to handle the situation to ensure patient safety is not compromised.

Taking annual leave to give yourself time to rest (2) is the next most appropriate option. This option shows that you realise the danger posed to patient safety by working through the pain. However, annual leave should not be taken due to illness, therefore making this an incorrect response to the scenario.

Asking a fellow doctor to help with your tasks (4) would be the next appropriate course of conduct so that you may share your workload to ensure that patients are not being overlooked. However, this may be unfair on your colleague as it is not their responsibility to complete your own jobs, and may jeopardise the quality of care that their patients are receiving. Furthermore, in this option you are continuing to work (although with a reduced workload due to your colleague), despite your reduced ability to concentrate, endangering patient safety.

The least appropriate conduct would be to continue on with your usual jobs and to keep your back pain to yourself (3). This is because you may be sacrificing patient safety by being tired during shifts, which may in turn affect your judgement in treating patients.

options: Phone 999 + then contact your medical indemnity provider for advice
Walk away from the situation to avoid a potential conflict of interest
Phone 999 + don't give benzylpenicillin
Phone 999 + ask a passerby who doesn't know the child to draw-up and give benzylpenicillin
Phone 999 + give benzylpenicillin to your friend's child
questions:
You are a GP registrar on a weekend away with a close friend and his wife. Their young child has been unwell since the morning and has now become pyrexial with an evolving purpuric rash. You have a drugs bag in the back of your car.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It is normally advised that doctors should not treat themselves or close family/friends. However, this question tests whether a doctor has the professional judgement to act appropriately in an emergency situation.

Given that the child may have meningococcal septicaemia it is vital that an ambulance is called for immediately. The decision is then what to do next. As this is an emergency situation you should give treatment. Phoning your medical indemnity provider for advice will take time but it is probable you will given advice that it is ok to give the benzylpenicillin prior to the ambulance arriving. Withholding the antibiotic is inappropriate in a child with potential meningococcal septicaemia. Giving the antibiotic to a passerby risks is inappropriate as it risks the wrong dose being given.

options: Do not alert anybody as your colleague is a doctor and will be using the drugs for the treatment of one of his patients
Ask your colleague what he is doing
Inform the police
Inform your consultant
Inform the ward manager
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a medical ward. You walk into the treatment room one day to see a fellow ST1 colleague putting items out of the drugs cabinet into his bag.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario is a very difficult situation to find yourself in. While you may jump to conclusions regarding the reasons why your colleague is placing medication into his bag, he may have a perfectly reasonable explanation and proof to support why he is doing it. It may be that your colleague is collecting the medication for an emergency procedure, for example local anaesthetic for a chest drain. However, there is a possibility that he is taking medications from the cabinet for his own personal gain. Therefore, asking what your colleague is doing (option 2) is the most appropriate response in this scenario

As the medications are being taken from the ward, the next most appropriate action to take would be to notify the ward manager (5). The ward manager is responsible for the ward, and a member of staff stealing medication from the ward is putting all of the patient on the ward at risk. Therefore, they should be notified.

Informing your consultant about what you have seen (option 4) is the next most appropriate option. Your consultant will be able to fully investigate what has happened and plan what to do next.
